Its synthesis is simpler and cheaper than that of ascorbic acid. 
 There are no known side effects to date, in the concentrations used or in doses lower than the acceptable daily intake. Daily intake: Up to 6 mg / kg of body weight.

info:
It is a synthetic food antioxidant. It is used to prevent the oxidation of fats. TBHQ is a synthetic derivative of hydroquinone and a member of the phenol family. Hydroquinones are one of the two main reagents in the defensive glands of Bombardier beetles. 
 It is also believed to be the active toxin of the fungus Agaricus hondensis. Cytotoxic, genotoxic, mutagenic and carcinogenic potentials are not excluded. 
 Precursor of stomach tumors in animals. Although it is clearly presented as an additive to avoid according to some sources, the official position is that the doses used in the processed diet are not a cause for concern. 
 Behavioral and / or hyperactivity disorders are also reported in children.   It is not recommended in children and pregnant women
title: Butylhydroxinon

info:

 BHA is strongly suspected of being carcinogenic   Other side effects reported: 
 Alteration of digestive enzyme synthesis in the liver 
  Increase in cholesterol and blood lipids, cumulative risk 
 Suspected hyperactivity in children.
title: Butylated Hydroxyanisole (BHA)

info:

 BHT is strongly suspected of being carcinogenic.  Other side effects reported: 
 Causes mutagenic effects, alters the blood composition. 
  Increase in cholesterol and blood lipids, cumulative risk 
 related to behavioral disorders (care for children).

info:

 Commercial lecithin comes mainly from soybean oil, which can be genetically modified. Other sources are egg yolks and legume seeds, including peanuts and corn, which can also be transgenic. 
 It is used to mix water and oil / fat. 
 Lecithins are often presented as non-toxic. Overdose can disturb the stomach, affect appetite and cause sweating   intense.

 According to her, A dose of oral anoxomer can be absorbed up to 0.2% in humans. There is not much information about this additive.

  Suspected mutagen, possibility of liver assignment,   The first target organs affected in guinea pigs are the liver and kidneys.

e_type: Miscellaneous - Citric Acid and its Salts
info:
Natural citric acid (E330) plays a central role in the metabolism of virtually all living organisms and takes its name from the lemon, where it is present in large quantities. 
 Today, the main commercial route of the production of citric acid is the culture of Aspergillus niger, fed with a substrate that contains sugar.   
 This microorganism can be transgenic to increase the yield. 
 The source of the sugar is macerated corn liquor, molasses, hydrolyzed corn starch or other low-cost sweet solutions.   
 Citric acid can also be obtained from a more expensive method using products derived from pineapple.   
 Citric acid is often presented as harmless,   except that it can attack tooth enamel, aphthosis, allergies / pseudo-allergies and other problems in a sensitive person, in high doses or in regular consumption.
title: Citric Acid

 Pure phosphoric acid is a corrosive substance, harmful by ingestion and by contact or even by inhalation. 
 It is usually used to replace citric acid (E330) because it is cheaper and easier to produce in large quantities.

info:

 According to a US scientific report (1957) from the National Institute of Health, triammonium citrate was the most toxic of the ammonium salts studied, from which an increase in the pH of the blood was observed. 
 In high doses can lead to disorders of liver function (more frequently), kidney, pancreatic, digestive disorders. 
 This substance causes severe irritation in the eyes, skin irritation and irritation of the respiratory tract.
title: Triammonium Citrate

info:
It is a synthetic acidifier, emulsifier and flavoring agent. Citrates are the salts of citric acid E330: E381 can be prepared by adding a ferric compound to an aqueous solution of ammonia and citric acid. 
 It is said to be less toxic, but its effects on health are not known.
title: Ammonium Ferric Citrate

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. Calcium glycerophosphate is the calcium salt of glycerophosphoric acid (glycerol-3-phosphate) that forms phosphoglycerides.  
 In processed food, phosphoric acid and additives derived from it or phosphate additives are doubtful because tolerable doses are not studied. 
 Special attention to the loss of bone calcium, osteoporosis, children (hyperactivity), kidneys, chronic renal failure.  They could promote the activity of known carcinogens.
title: Calcium glycerophosphate

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. Isopropyl alcohol is used with citric acid to obtain isopropyl citrate. Few studies and toxicological data available. 
 The oncological safety of pure isopropyl alcohol is not established and is classified as an unclassifiable agent due to its carcinogenicity for humans in IARC.
title: Isopropyl citrates

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant.  
 Its ability to  coat  metals allows, however, to be used in medicine for the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. 
 Causes mineral imbalance. It is a known enzyme and blood coagulant inhibitor. 
  Not recommended in children or pregnant women. 
 In low doses it inhibits the absorption of minerals and iron. 
 In large doses causes vomiting, diarrhea and stomach pains.    The E385 is made of raw materials known to be toxic or carcinogenic.
title: Calcium disodium ethylenediamine

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. Its main chemical characteristic is its high chelating power, so it forms highly stable metal complexes. 
 Its ability to  coat metals allows, however, to be used in medicine for the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. In short, it is capable of coating the metal molecules to prevent their activity. 
 Not recommended in children or pregnant women. 
 In low doses it inhibits the absorption of minerals and iron. 
  In large doses causes vomiting, diarrhea and stomach pains.
title: Disodium ethylenediamine tetra-acetate

info:
It  is a synthetic stabilizer. The origin of this additive is a mixture of glycerides of stearic acid and other fatty acids. 
 Its main function is to increase the viscosity of the food without substantially modifying other properties such as taste.
title: Oxystearin

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. Thiodipropionic acid is a synthetic sulfur compound. 
 Pure thiodipropionic acid is an irritant to the skin, eyes and respiratory tract.
title: Thiodipropionic acid

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. E389 is a chemical in the form of white flakes with a sweet smell, soluble in most organic solvents, and used as an antioxidant in edible fats and oils. 
 Pure thiodipropionic acid is an irritant to the skin, eyes and respiratory tract.
title: Dilauryl thiodipropionate

info:
It is a synthetic antioxidant. Distearyl thiodipropionate (E390) is an artificial chemical made from thiodipropionic acid (E388) and a fatty alcohol, stearyl alcohol, stearic acid derivative or other fats. 
 Pure thiodipropionic acid is an irritant to the skin, eyes and respiratory tract.
title: Distearyl thiodipropionate

info:
It is a natural or synthetic antioxidant. Phytic acid is a biomolecule found naturally in the seeds of many grains and legumes, usually in the form of a calcium or magnesium salt. 
 The substance is a source of phosphorus in plants, a signal transfer agent and an antioxidant in human cells.
title: Phytic acid

info:
It is a natural or synthetic antioxidant. Its function is to protect the food from deterioration caused by oxidation. 
 Additive extracted from rosemary by chemical solvents, depending on the decline one or more stages of additional chemical treatments such as deodorization and / or discoloration. 
 The additive can be produced according to the biological specifications. Ethanol is no longer required. The E392 in the recommended doses is not very toxic.
title: Rosemary extract

info:
It  is a natural or synthetic antioxidant. Its function is to maintain the uniform dispersion of substances in a food. Calcium lactobionate is the chemical bond of a mineral salt, calcium, with lactobionic acid.   
 Lactobionic acid is composed of gluconic acid (E574) and galactose. It can be formed by oxidation of lactose.
title: Calcium lactobionate

info:

 Alginic acid and alginates occupy many technological functions in the processed diet, such as gelling agents, coating agents, humectants and thickeners. 
 Alginic acid and alginates are also found in some cosmetics, some pharmaceuticals, paints and printing inks. 
 There are no known side effects to date. In large doses the absorption of important nutrients in the intestine, possibility of water retention, laxative effect.

info:
It is a natural foaming, thickener and gelling agent. Obtained by extraction of brown or red seaweeds, of the family Gelidiaceae, Sphaerococcaceae and Rhodophyceae. 
 Agar contains combinations of very long and complex sugars (polysaccharides) that the intestine can not assimilate and leave to ferment: avoid high doses, the risk of flatulence, the laxative effect of swelling and diarrhea. 
 The agar-agar (E406) has many technological functions in processed foods, is included in the Codex Alimentarius as coating agent, gelling agent, humectant, stabilizer, thickener, filler, carrier, emulsifier and gelling agent.
title: Agar

info:
It is a natural foaming, gelling agent. It is obtained by extraction of red marine algae from the Rodoficeas family. 
 They are washed, crushed and the paste that is obtained is then treated chemically.    
 These are toxic risks and cancers, particularly gastrointestinal       Not recommended in children and pregnant women. 
 Currently, several companies in the market have decided to withdraw this additive due to the pressure of consumers, who complained more about its use in children's products and food aimed at children.
title: Carrageenan

info:
It is a natural foaming, gelling agent. It is obtained by extraction of red marine algae from the Rodoficeas family.

 Not recommended in children and pregnant women. Currently, several companies in the market have decided to withdraw this additive due to the pressure of consumers, who complained more about its use in children's products and food aimed at children.
title: Processed euchema seaweed

info: emulsifier
title: Processed eucheuma seaweed (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

info:
It is a natural stabilizer, thickener and gelling agent. The glycans are polysaccharides / oligosaccharides. A natural polysaccharide, produced from marine algae (Furcellaria fastigata) in Denmark. 
 In the case of this additive, they are extracted from baker's yeast. In its natural state, baking yeast glycan has a beneficial effect on the immune system. 
 There is not much information about the E408, for now its side effect in people is unknown.
title: Bakers yeast glycan

info:
It is a natural stabilizer, thickener and gelling agent. Arabinogalactan is a molecule called polysaccharide present in varying amounts in many plants, fungi and bacteria. 
 The additive is probably extracted with larch wood water. In the field of plants, it is one of the main constituents of several gums, such as gum arabic, rubber gum, etc.). 
  In the human diet, many plants provide small amounts of arabinogalactans, including carrots, radishes, tomatoes, pears and wheat.
title: Arabinogalactan

info:
It is a natural stabilizer, thickener and gelling agent. It is obtained by extracting and pressing the seeds of the carob tree (Ceratonia siliqua), which is found mainly in the Mediterranean basin. 
 There are reports that show that it is harmless in moderate doses. Sometimes cases of allergy are reported. 
 In high doses: possible laxative effect, flatulence, abdominal distension. The carob bean flour is indigestible and swells a lot in the intestine.
title: Locust Bean Gum

info:
It is a natural stabilizer and thickener. Oatmeal is an extract of a polysaccharide plant produced from oats. 
 There would be no known side effects in the concentrations used. It would not be suitable for those intolerant to gluten.
title: Oat gum

info:
It is a natural stabilizer and thickener. Guar gum (E412) is a polysaccharide of natural origin extracted from the seed of the legume Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, a plant also known as guar or guar bean and native to parts of West Africa, Pakistan and India. 
 The positive effects studied at high doses (between one and several tens of grams per day) have shown interest in diabetics and cholesterolemia. The additive is generally considered harmless.
title: Guar Gum

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. The exudate flows naturally or by incision in the trunk and branches of different fabaceae, including the astragalus gummifer. 
 Complex mixture of several polysaccharides. The medicine gives various medicinal properties, among others, as a laxative, antitussive, against digestive disorders or as a dressing for burns. 
 No side effects have been found. At large doses can cause flatulence, diarrhea, allergy or abdominal cramps.
title: Tragacanth gum

info:
It  is a natural thickener and emulsifier. It is obtained by scarring in the stems of the Acacias family trees, specifically of 2 species: Senegalia and Vachellia, which grow in the regions of Senegal and Sudan. 
 It is used to be an emulsifier of essential oils such as lemon or orange in food. It is also used in cosmetics and perfumes. 
 No side effects have been found. But in large doses can cause allergies, inhibit the absorption of minerals and damage the activity of various enzymes.
title: Gum Acacia (Gum Arabic)

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. Of natural origin, non-digestible polysaccharide, secretion produced by the fermentation of sugar by a microorganism, then purification by recovery with isopropyl alcohol. 
 No side effects have been found. But it is not recommended in newborn babies and pregnant women. In large doses it has a high laxative effect.
title: Xanthan Gum

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent.     It is extracted from the dried and processed resin, polysaccharide harvested in the woody tissue of the Sterculia urens plant (Sterculiaceae family) native to India, as well as other related species. Unlike other similar gums, it is soluble in cold water.     
 No side effects have been found. In large doses can cause abdominal distension, diarrhea or digestive disorders
title: Karaya Gum

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. Tara gum, also called Peruvian carob, is extracted from the seed of Caesalpinia spinosa, a shrub native to South America. 
 It is estimated that tara gum has no side effects with the normal dietary dose. 
 No side effects have been found. In high doses, risk of flatulence and abdominal distension (intestinal fermentation of this non-digestible polysaccharide). 
 It would be difficult to reach high doses due to the viscosity of the substance.
title: Tara gum

info:
It is a synthetic thickener and gelling agent. Gellan gum is a polysaccharide produced by the fermentation of   Arbohydrates by bacteriological strains of Pseudomonas elodea. The extraction is carried out by precipitation in isopropyl alcohol. 
 No side effects have been found.
title: Gellan gum

info:
It is a natural thickener and stabilizer. E419 is a water-soluble polysaccharide extracted from Anogeissus latifolia, a medium-sized tree native to parts of India, Sri Lanka, Nepal and Burma.  
 No side effects have been found. Little information available, a priori not very dangerous, except perhaps in high doses as the totality of the gums of the transformed diet (digestive disorder, diarrhea, gases) and the possibility of allergic reaction.
title: Gum ghatti

info:
It is a natural sweetener, moisturizer, emulsifier and sequestrant. Sorbitol exists naturally in fruits (prunes, plums, peaches, etc.) and takes its name from the sorbidor whose berries contain a lot. 
 Commercially, the additive is synthesized from starch (in whole or in part corn) from which several enzymes produce glucose. This glucose is then converted chemically into sorbitol. In low doses it causes flatulence, diarrhea and may aggravate irritable bowel syndrome.     
 Its use in foods for children under 1 year is not allowed because it can cause severe diarrhea.
title: Sorbitols

info:
It is a natural sweetener. Mannitol exists in its natural state (plants, algae, fungi). To date, there are three main manufacturing methods: industrial synthesis, fermentation with microorganisms and direct extraction of natural products. 
 The additive would be commonly produced by industrial technology, which consists of the hydrogenation of a fructose produced from starches by the action of microorganisms (yeast). 
 In large doses causes flatulence and diarrhea. It is contraindicated in people suffering from heart failure.
title: Mannitol

info:
It is a synthetic and moisturizing sweetener. It is achieved by synthesis of glycerides, these can be of animal origin (extracted from the skin of cattle and pigs) or of vegetable origin (extracted from coconut oil and other vegetable oils). E420 is not very dangerous in foods, however, it could, according to some sources, be transgenic. 
 High doses: laxative, diarrhea, flatulence, diuretic effect, thirst sensation, hyperglycemia, nausea, headache, hypertension. It is sold as a laxative form of its host to glycerol. 
 It would not be recommended for pregnant or lactating women.
title: Glycerol

info: It is a synthetic emulsifier. To manufacture this additive, the gum arabic modified with octenylsuccinic acid is used. Its function is that of an agent that forms or preserves a mixture of substances that normally can not be mixed, for example: oil and water.
title: Octenyl succinic acid (OSA) modified gum arabic

info:
It is a stabilizer, thickener and gelling agent. A polysaccharide produced by alkaline bacteria such as Alcaligenes faecalis. Alcaligenes faecalis is an aerobic organism that is often found in the environment. 
 It was named for its discovery in the feces, but later it also proved to be much more common elsewhere. 
 Alcaligenes faecalis is normally found in soil, water and environments related to people. 
 No side effects have been found.
title: Curdlan

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. The polysaccharide is extracted from the tubers of Amorphophallus konjac, a plant of the family Araceae that grows naturally in the forests of Thailand, Vietnam and southern China. 
 No side effects have been found. It is not very dangerous, with the notable exceptions of asphyxia by ingestion in the form of gelatin confectionery.
title: Konjac flour

info:
It is a natural thickener and stabilizer. It is obtained by the extraction of soy fiber. 
 No side effects have been found, but it is possible that it is transgenic and allergenic.
title: Soybean hemicellulose

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. Cassia gum is a dietary fiber of polysaccharides, obtained from the seeds of plants of the genus Cassia and Senna. 
 Normally, it is known safely in the animal model, but allergic reactions have occurred in humans with other products derived from cassia.
title: Cassia gum

info:
It is a natural thickener. Denatured collagen, a complex mixture of proteins obtained by the prolonged boiling of tendons, ligaments, bones or hides of pig or calf. 
 Unlike the United States and Canada, EU gelatin It is no longer considered an additive but an ingredient. Previously, gelatin occupied the number E441 in Europe. 
 Today, outside of Europe, it occupies number 428 on the international list official food additives.  It can cause various allergies, asthma, etc.
title: Gelatin

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier. A peptone is a substance that results from the transformation of proteins, usually the product of a hydrolysis reaction. 
 This hydrolysis can be chemical or enzymatic, the raw materials can be animal, lactic or vegetable (soy, cotton, corn, beans, wheat, ...). 
 No side effects are known, at the moment.   For now there is not much information for this additive.
title: Peptones

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and emulsifier. Synthetic compound produced from ethylene oxide and a fatty acid: stearic acid. 
 Polyoxyethylenes contain fatty acids almost always derived from vegetable oils, but the use of animal fats, including pork, is not totally excluded and remains at the discretion of the producer. 
 Probably the carcinogenic effects, as well as the reproductive effects observed in laboratory animals. 
 Possibility of allergy to the skin in some people, digestive disorders, effects on the gastrointestinal tract (hypermotility, diarrhea, inflammation), metabolism, liver assignment.

info:
Polyoxyethylene- (20) -sorbitan monostearate and its relatives, POLYSORBATE 65 and 80, work the same way as mono-and diglycerides, but smaller amounts are required to achieve the same result. 
 They help prevent baked goods from going stale, keep dill oil dissolved in bottled dill pickles, help coffee whiteners dissolve in coffee, and prevent oil from separating out of artificial whipped cream. 
 An emulsifier and thickener found in bakery products, frozen desserts, imitation dairy products, emulsified sauces and soups. 
 Other uses include products such as creams, lotions, pomades, sunscreens, shampoos, conditioners, skin protection creams, salves, pharmaceutical ointments, and other emulsions.
title: Polyoxyethylene (20) sorbitan monostearate

title: Pectins (i) pectin (ii) amidated pectin

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent. Pectin is a polysaccharide that makes up the cells of plant tissues.  
  Commercial pectin, which is often used to thicken jams and jellies, is extracted from dried apple marc, dried bark (both fruit juice and cider residues) or citrus mesocarps. 
 By hot addition of diluted acid.  
 No side effects have been found.
title: Pectins

info:
It is a natural thickener and gelling agent.    Pectin is a polysaccharide that makes up the cells of plant tissues. Commercial pectin, which is often used to thicken jams and jellies, is extracted from dried apple marc, dried bark (both fruit juice and cider residues) or citrus mesocarps. By hot addition of diluted acid.    
 The treatment of the initial pectin with a dilute acid gives weakly esterified pectins. When this process comprises ammonium hydroxide (ammonia), the amidated pectins (E440 B) are obtained. 
 No side effects have been found.
title: Amidated Pectin

info:
It  is a synthetic emulsifier.  Hydrogenated oil is an oil treated with hydrogen injection at high pressure, the term  superglycerin indicates that an excess of glycerol has been added later. 
 It is known that partially hydrogenated and, to a lesser extent, fully hydrogenated oils are harmful, including weight problems, cholesterol, cardiovascular diseases, cancers, autoimmune diseases and allergies.
title: Superglycerinated hydrogenated rapeseed oil

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier.   Ammonium salts of phosphatidic acid, a mixture of ammonium salts of phosphorylated glycerides. 
 The phosphatidic acid is it is usually derived from partially cured (partially hydrogenated) rapeseed oil.  
 In low doses European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), does not report any health problems. 
 In large doses can cause digestive problems and inhibit the assimilation of minerals.
title: Ammonium salts of phosphatidic acid

info:
It is an emulsifier and stabilizer.   The brominated vegetable oil is bonded to the atoms of the bromine element. Bromine is a substance for smoking with an acrid odor classified in toxic gases and vapors, it is very toxic by inhalation, ingestion and contact.   Brominated vegetable oil is little studied. 
 It is known that brominated compounds are toxic (or even carcinogenic), neurotoxic and genotoxic.
title: Brominated vegetable oils

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and emulsifier. It is a chemical mixture of sucrose esters with acetic and isobutyric acids. It comes in the form of a clear liquid, straw-colored, transparent, without deposits and with a mild odor. 
 This substance causes the suspended elements not to settle on the bottom of the bottle   and remain scattered throughout the drink. 
 In large doses can cause alterations in the liver and bile in laboratory animals,  it remains to be proven if it is the same effect in humans.
title: Sucrose acetate isobutyrate

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer. It is obtained by reaction of the resin extracted from old pines and firs with Glycerol (E422), which gives it a sweet taste.    It is divided into 3 classes: Resin Glyceride Esters, Glyceride Esters of Pine Oil Rosin and Glyceride Esters of Wood Rosin.      
 No side effects have been found.   
 High intakes can alter calcium / phosphate balance, headache, nausea, vomiting,  dehydration, diarrhea, thirst, dizziness and confusion.
title: Glycerol esters of rosin

info: It is an emulsifier.  There is not much information for this additive.   No side effects have been found.    It is an ester of succinic acid (E363) and a saturated fatty acid, stearic acid (E570).
title: Succistearin

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and acidity regulator.  You get derivatives of phosphoric acid (E338).  
 This additive is divided into 9 classes: Disodium Diphosphate, Trisodium Diphosphate, Tetrasodium Diphosphate,Dipotassium Diphosphate, Tetrapotassium Diphosphate, Dicalcium Diphosphate, Calcium Acid Diphosphate, Dimagnic Diphosphate and Dihydrogen Magnesium Diphosphate.   
  Special attention to the loss of bone calcium, osteoporosis, children (hyperactivity and other behavioral disorders), kidneys, chronic renal failure. 
 They could promote the activity of known carcinogens.
title: Diphosphates

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizers and acidity regulator.     You get derivatives of phosphoric acid (E338).   
 This additive is divided into 3 classes: Pentasodium Triphosphate, Pentapotassium Triphosphate and Sodium-Potassium Triphosphate.    
 Special attention to the loss of bone calcium, osteoporosis, children (hyperactivity and others)   behavioral disorders), kidneys, chronic renal failure. 
 They could promote the activity of known carcinogens.
title: Triphosphates

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and acidity regulator.     You get derivatives of phosphoric acid (E338).   
 This additive is divided into 3 classes: Sodium Polyphosphate, Potassium Polyphosphate, Sodium-Calcium Polyphosphate, Calcium Polyphosphate and Ammonium Polyphosphate.  
  Special attention to the loss of bone calcium, osteoporosis, children (hyperactivity and others)   behavioral disorders), kidneys, chronic renal failure.     
 They could promote the activity of known carcinogens.
title: Polyphosphates

info:
It is a stabilizer.    Potassium polyaspartate is the potassium salt of a polymer of aspartic acid, one of the 20 amino acids that make up proteins.     
 Improves the quality of maintenance and stability of wine and its use does not have an impact on sensory properties.   
  It is a recent additive.   Few data available. Officially the additive is reported harmless.
title: Potassium Polyaspartate

info:
It is a stabilizer and thickener.    Alpha Cyclodextrin is a saccharide in the form of a circular cage of natural origin that It allows to encapsulate several molecules, in particular the aromas.   
 The product is obtained by the action of an enzyme produced by a bacterium in the starch   partially hydrolyzed.    
 They are used in the food, pharmaceutical and chemical industries, as well as in agricultural engineering and environmental.    Alpha Cyclodextrin is synthesized through an enzyme whose gene encoder comes from a bacillus fecal flora.This can be toxic to health.
title: Cyclodextrin

info:
It is a stabilizer and thickener.   The gamma-cyclodextrin is a saccharide in the form of a circular cage of natural origin that allows to encapsulate various molecules, in particular the aromas. 
 The product is obtained by the action of an enzyme produced by a bacterium in the partially hydrolyzed starch.    
 The agri-food industry has commonly (and for more than 20 years in Japan) used cyclodextrins as a flavor enhancer by allowing easy addition of flavor compounds or by fixing molecules that are too volatile and prolonging, for example, the flavor duration of the gums of chew.     
 Few data available. Officially the additive is reported harmless.
title: Gamma-cyclodextrin

info:
It is a stabilizer and thickener.    A cycle-dextrin is a cage molecule used to encapsulate several molecules of food additives, flavors and vitamins, among others.    
  The agri-food industry has commonly (and for more than 20 years in Japan) used cyclodextrins as a flavor enhancer by allowing easy addition of flavor compounds or by fixing molecules that are too volatile and prolonging. 
 Beta-cyclodextrin appears more frequently as safe .
title: beta-Cyclodextrin

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and thickener.    Natural cellulose is a non-digestible carbohydrate for humans that consists of in a long chain of molecules of D-Glucose, which is the main constituent of plants and, in particular, the walls of your cells. 
    Cotton is an important source (90%), as well as wood. 
  Reported inoffensive but not unanimously: conflicting reports and cancer risks.
title: Celluloses

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and thickener. It is obtained by the treatment with mineral acids of alpha-cellulose extracted from vegetable fibers, these fibers come from a high percentage of cotton.   
 Found in sterilised, pasteurised and UHT cream, low-calorie cream and pasteurised low-fat cream, laxatives, sun creams and amongst other things, wallpaper paste.  
 May cause asthma, intestinal blockage, itching, skin rash and swallowing difficulty.
title: Methyl cellulose

info:
It is a synthetic stabilizer and thickener.    It is obtained by the treatment with mineral acids of alpha-cellulose extracted from vegetable fibers, these fibers come from a high percentage of cotton. 
 There are conflicting reports. Cellulose is not digestible for humans but can be fermented in the large intestine and colon in the form of fibers, however, the long-term effect on habitual consumption of artificially added fiber in food has not yet been studied in people.

Sodium carboxymethylcellulose (E466), which is hydrolyzed by the fungus Trichoderma reesei cellulase (obtained by the treatment with mineral acids of alpha-cellulose).

 It is also used in preparations of vitamins and minerals (nutrients), enzymes, and also as an additive. 
 There are reports that cellulose is not digestible for humans but can be fermented in the large intestine and colon in the form of fibers.
title: Sodium carboxymethyl cellulose

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier, stabilizer and antiglare.    
 A set of fatty acids chemically bound with aluminum, ammonium, calcium, potassium and / or sodium. 
  Fatty acids are originally found in animal and plant cells.    E470 is certainly doubtful if it is not toxic due to its possible aluminum (E173) and / or ammonium content.
title: Salts of fatty acids

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier, stabilizer and anticaking. Fatty acids are originally found in animal and plant cells. 
 The additive is formed by a mixture of stearic, oleic, palmitic and myristic acids and then chemically linked with sodium, potassium and / or calcium.  
 The raw materials used are mainly edible fats (soy, corn, rapeseed), probably transgenic; However, a source of animal fat is also possible, including pork. 
 Currently serious harmful effects are admitted, such as breast cancer, hypercholesterolemia, atherosclerosis, diabetes (insulin resistance), cardiovascular risks, hepatic dysfunction, reproductive toxicity with obstetric effects, as psychiatric consequences proven or suspected.

title: Magnesium stearate

info:
It is a natural emulsifier and antioxidant.   Mono and diglycerides are products of the degradation of fats.   It is used to lengthen the time of a product and to be in a wet state (avoid drying).  
  The most used raw material is vegetable: soybean oil, which is usually extracted from a total or partially transgenic plant. This oil can also be hydrogenated. However, a source of animal fat, including pork.  
  To extract vegetable fatty acids, toxic hydrocarbon derivatives such as hexane or tetrachlorethylene are often used.   
  Currently serious harmful effects are admitted, such as breast cancer, hypercholesterolemia, atherosclerosis, diabetes (insulin resistance), cardiovascular risks, hepatic dysfunction, reproductive toxicity with obstetric effects, as psychiatric consequences proven or suspected.

 The additive officially contains a very small amount of oxirane, a toxic and carcinogenic agent. It is used in oils to make frying and industrial oils.

It is a natural emulsifier and an antioxidant.   Produced by reaction between a suitable alcohol and anhydrous maleic acid, followed by a reaction with sodium bisulfite. 
 Little information available as a food additive.   Several sources report a possible laxative effect.
title: Dioctyl sodium sulfosuccinate

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier and a stabilizer. It is composed of stearic acid (a saturated fatty acid), lactic acid (E270) and is neutralized with the sodium base. 
 It is often reported that they are harmless or harmless within the limits of the allowable daily intake. It is an additive whose safety is little known, risk of digestive disorders.
title: Sodium lactylates

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier and a stabilizer. It is composed of stearic acid (a saturated fatty acid), lactic acid (E270) and is neutralized with the sodium base. It is divided into 2 classes: Stearoyl calcium lactylate and calcium oleic lactylate. 
 It is often reported that they are harmless or harmless within the limits of the allowable daily intake. 
 It is an additive whose safety is little known, risk of digestive disorders.
title: Calcium lactylates

info:
It is a synthetic emulsifier and a stabilizer.   A combination of stearic acid and tartaric acid (E334), which results in a mixture of several compounds.  
 Tartaric acid exists, among other things, in abundance in grapes. It is the origin of the tartar deposited in the wine bottles.   Stearic acid is a fatty acid that is abundant in all animal or vegetable fats to a lesser extent. 
 Its commercial version is often a mixture of stearic and palmitic acid. 
 It is often reported that they are harmless or harmless within the limits of the allowable daily intake. It is an additive whose safety is little known, risk of digestive disorders.
title: Stearyl tartrate

info:
A combination of stearic acid and citric acid, which results in a mixture of several compounds.   Stearic acid is a fatty acid that is abundant in all animal or vegetable fats to a lesser extent. 
 Its commercial version is often a mixture of stearic and palmitic acid. 
 In general it is reported harmless.   It is a chemical whose safety is little known, with risk of digestive alterations.
title: Stearyl citrate

info:
It is a synthetic ester of fumaric acid (E297) and stearic acid (E570). A second chemical reaction makes it possible to produce a sodium salt. 
 The origin is fat (animal or vegetable).   It is used to form or preserve a mixture of substances that normally can not be mixed, for example: oil and water.  
 It does not appear to be subject to special precautions, although the pure substance is dangerous by ingestion.
title: Sodium stearoyl fumarate

info:
It is a synthetic ester of fumaric acid (E297) and stearic acid (E570). A second chemical reaction makes it possible to produce a calcium salt. 
 The origin is fat (animal or vegetable).   It is used to form or preserve a mixture of substances that normally can not be mixed, for example: oil and water.  
 It does not appear to be subject to special precautions, although the pure substance is dangerous by ingestion.
title: Calcium stearoyl fumarate

info:
It is a synthetic ester of lauric acid (E297) and sulfuric acid (E570). This ester is neutralized with sodium carbonate (E500i). 
 It is a strong ionic surfactant that, in addition to its food allocation by Codex, is used in household products such as toothpastes, shampoos, shaving foams or bubble baths for its thickening effects and its ability to create a foam. 
 It is generally synthesized by treating lauric alcohol with sulfur trioxide gas (industrial method). 
 The product obtained is then neutralized by the addition of sodium hydroxide or carbonate. Lauryl alcohol is usually derived from cheap coconut or palm oil by hydrolysis, which releases its fatty acids, followed by hydrogenation. 
 The pure substance remains classified as harmful by ingestion, inhalation and dermal absorption. There are toxic effects by ingestion. These are reactions of allergic sensitivity through cosmetics, toothpastes, etc. that are reported more frequently.
title: Sodium laurylsulfate

info:
The ethoxylated mono and diglycerides are made of edible fats. These fats come mainly from plants, but an animal source is not excluded. 
  Edible fats are broken down with glycerin in a process called glycerolysis to give the mono and diglycerides.    Mono and diglycerides of fatty acids E471, of which E488 is derived from the reaction with ethylene oxide. 
 The ethoxylated mono- and diglycerides are distinguished essentially by an additional reaction with ethylene oxide, a carcinogenic listed compound.
title: Ethoxylated mono- and di-glycerides

  These doses would be reached from 150 grams of fine pasta or 300 grams of dessert or sweet.

info:
Its origin comes from sources rich in plant phytosterols, such as sea buckthorn oil, corn oil, sunflower oil and soybean oil. 
 Its main function is to enrich foods and attribute healthier properties. No side effects have been found. 
 The total daily consumption of more than 3 grams of plant sterols is not recommended.
title: Phytosterols Rich in Stigmasterol

info:
Sodium salt of carbonic acid. Natural substance, present as saline deposits left by the water of alkaline lakes. 
 It is also synthesized through the Solvay process or by electrolysis of seawater.    Today, the Solvay process is an important part of the global market. The main characteristics of this process are the use of ammonia and carbon dioxide (E290) with sodium chloride.  
  No side effects have been found. In large doses can irritate, corrode the gastrointestinal tract, electrolyte disturbances, vomiting, diarrhea, concussion.
title: Sodium carbonates

info:
Potassium salt of carbonic acid. Nowadays, commercial potassium carbonate is prepared by electrolysis of potassium chloride (E508). 
 The resulting potassium hydroxide (E525) is then carbonized with carbon dioxide (E290) to form potassium carbonate. 
 No side effects have been found. In large doses can irritate the digestive tract
title: Potassium carbonates

info:
Ammonium carbonate is prepared by sublimation of a mixture of ammonium sulfate and calcium carbonate, or by passing gaseous carbon dioxide through an absorption column containing an aqueous solution of ammonia and causing distillation. 
  Ammonium carbonate decomposes slowly in several products. In ambient air, but also in hot water, it releases ammonia and carbon dioxide.  
  In high doses can deteriorate the acid / base balance of the body, the pH of the urine. Loss of magnesium, calcium and phosphate. It can irritate the digestive tract.
title: Ammonium carbonates

info:
Magnesium carbonate is usually obtained by extraction of the mineral.  
 Magnesium carbonate can also be synthesized by exposing a slurry of magnesium hydroxide to carbon dioxide under pressure, producing soluble magnesium bicarbonate.  
 It is divided into 2 classes: Magnesium Carbonate and Magnesium Bicarbonate.  
  No side effects have been found.
title: Magnesium carbonates

info:
It is an iron salt, existing in its natural state or obtained synthetically. The   food iron carbonate would be prepared by treating solutions of iron salts with alkali carbonate salts. 
   No side effects have been found. 
 The ingestion of high doses of iron is toxic. Care for people with hemochromatosis.
title: Ferrous carbonate

info:
It is a very powerful acid manufactured by synthesis.   Hydrochloric acid exists in its natural state as the main constituent of gastric acids. It exists naturally, in your stomach, it is the main component of stomach acids.  
  Discovered by the Arab alchemist Jabir Ibn Hayyan around the year 800.    It is used to purify drinking water. 
   At low doses, no side effects have been found.   But at great doses it can provoke erosion of the mucous membranes of the esophagus and stomach. 
 The respiratory system as well as the blood circulation may also be affected.
title: Hydrochloric Acid

info:
Salt of hydrochloric acid combined with this metal.    It occurs in the form of discolored, elongated, prismatic or cubic crystals, or granular white powder. Without smell.  
  In low doses, no side effects have been found. Although some people cause digestive problems.   But at large doses can cause diarrhea, intestinal ulcers and bleeding.
title: Potassium chloride

info:
Calcium chloride exists in its natural state. But usually it is derived from the salt of Hydrochloric Acid (E507).    It is commercially manufactured in 3 ways: 
 (1) by refining salty natural waters, 
 (2) by reaction of calcium hydroxide with ammonium chloride in the synthetic process of Solvay, and 
 (3) by reaction of acid Hydrochloric acid with calcium carbonate.  
  In large quantities can cause: digestion disorders, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, intestinal ulcers and bleeding, disorders of the heart system.
title: Calcium chloride

info:
Ammonium chloride is the ammoniacal salt of hydrochloric acid. In nature, it appears in volcanic regions, settling on the rocks near the volcano's chimneys. It is also found in deep mines.    
 Ammonium chloride is prepared industrially by reaction of ammonia with hydrogen chloride. 
 It can be produced industrially in several ways, in particular through the Solvay process.    
 Ammonium chloride as a food additive is reported, according to the sources consulted, as harmful or harmless. 
 In large quantities can cause: Headache, nausea and vomiting.
title: Ammonium chloride

info:
Magnesium chloride is the magnesium salt of hydrochloric acid. It is a compound of natural origin, in particular extracted from seawater by hydrolysis, or from mines (carnallite, bischofite) or synthetically derived from the salt of Hydrochloric Acid (E507). 
 In low doses, no side effects have been found. In large doses could cause digestive discomfort and diarrhea. 
 Caution should be exercised in case of taking antibiotics, as it may decrease the effectiveness of some of them.
title: Magnesium chloride

info:
It is obtained from the derivative of the salt of Hydrochloric Acid (E507). 
 Tin chloride can be prepared by dissolving tin metal in hydrochloric acid, the reaction takes time. 
 It is established that pure tin chloride is dangerous by ingestion. In large doses it could cause digestive discomfort and diarrhea.
title: Stannous chloride

info:
Sulfuric acid is manufactured synthetically, mainly from sulfur, oxygen and water, through a process called contact involving a catalyst, but other processes are also implemented on a smaller scale. 
 Pure sulfuric acid is very corrosive, harmful by ingestion, contact and inhalation. 
 It is the vitriol and acid from car batteries. 
 In large doses it is lethal for an adult is between a teaspoon and a half ounce (approximately 15 ml).  There is a carcinogenic and / or carcinogenic effect by inhalation. 
 Normally it is not used in food products. It is used to make fertilizers and detergents.
title: Sulfuric acid

info:
Salt of sulfuric acid combined with sodium, natural or synthetic. It is divided into two classes: Sodium Sulfate and Partner Acid Sulfate. 
  No side effects have been found in low doses. However, in large doses, it can cause: diarrhea and digestive disorders. It is also used in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, cleaning products and detergent manufacturing.
title: Sodium sulfates

info:
Potassium salt of sulfuric acid, natural or synthetic. It is divided into two classes: Potassium Sulfate and Potassium Acid Sulfate. 
 No side effects have been found in low doses. However, in large doses, it can cause: diarrhea and digestive disorders. 
  It is also used in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, cleaning products and detergent manufacturing.
title: Potassium sulfates

info:
Calcium salt of sulfuric acid. Of natural or synthetic origin. It is divided into two classes: Calcium Sulfate and Calcium Acid Sulfate. 
 No side effects have been found in low doses. On the other hand, in large doses it can cause: intestinal obstruction and digestive disorders.  
 It is also used in pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, cleaning products and detergent manufacturing.
title: Calcium sulfate

info:
Ammonium salt of sulfuric acid, natural or synthetic. It is divided into two classes: Ammonium Sulfate and Ammonium Acid Sulfate. 
 The pure substance is dangerous by contact, ingestion and inhalation. It is potentially mutagenic. 
 No side effects have been found in low doses. However, in large doses it can cause: diarrhea, digestive disorders, cardiac contraction, hypertension. 
 It is also used in pharmaceuticals and cosmetics.
title: Ammonium sulfate

info:
Magnesium sulfate, or magnesium salt of sulfuric acid, is a compound that contains magnesium, sulfur and oxygen, can be natural or synthetic. It is divided into two classes: Magnesium Sulfate and Magnesium Acid Sulfate. 
 Natural magnesium sulfate and pharmacopoeia: Epsom salt has been used for centuries for several indications: treatment of skin problems, cardiac arrhythmia, eclampsia, asthma, laxative, additive for mineralized baths, nail growth problem. 
 No side effects have been found in low doses. 
 However, in large doses it can cause intestinal problems.
title: Magnesium sulfate

info:
Copper sulfate is a copper salt of sulfuric acid, it can be either naturally or synthetically. It is divided into two classes: Copper Sulfate and Copper Acid Sulfate.  
 Copper is a paradoxical mineral element, beneficial in the form of trace elements, but can become, in certain conditions, very toxic to humans and certain animals. 
 It is sometimes used to purify drinking water. 
 Copper sulfate is a toxic product for humans and for the environment. 
 In large doses it can cause kidney toxicity, cause of blood disorders, it also causes gastrointestinal-intestinal disorders and is considered neurotoxic.
title: Cupric sulfate

info:
Aluminum salt of sulfuric acid, can be natural or synthetic.  
  The anhydrous form naturally exists in the form of a rare mineral (millosevichite), found, for example, in a volcanic environment and by burning the waste from coal mines. It is sometimes used to purify drinking water. and also in cosmetics and some medications.   
 In large doses it is suspected that it promotes the onset of Alzheimer's disease, or Parkinson's disease.  
 It can also cause kidney toxicity.
title: Aluminium sulfate

info:
Salt of aluminum and sulfuric acid of sodium, can be of natural or synthetic form.    It is rarely obtained naturally by the known natural mineral forms of aluminum sulfate and sodium are mendozite and tamarugite. It is usually produced synthetically by a bond of sodium sulfate and aluminum sulfate.  
  It is sometimes used to purify drinking water. and also in refined sugar and as a food additive.    In large doses it is suspected that it promotes the onset of Alzheimer's disease, or Parkinson's disease. It can also cause kidney toxicity.
title: Aluminium sodium sulfate

info:
Prepared from natural aluminium sulphate. 
 It is used as acid source in baking powder for bakery products, baked at high temperature. It also stabilises colours. 
 It is sometimes used to purify drinking water. 
 Used in Industrial baking powder. Acceptable daily intake is upto 0. 6 mg/kg bodyweight. 
 Aluminium inhibits the uptake of B-vitamins. 
 It may also influence liver function in high concentrations. 
 In large doses it is suspected that it promotes the onset of Alzheimer's disease, or Parkinson's disease. 
 It can also cause kidney toxicity.
title: Aluminium potassium sulfate

info:
Salt of aluminum and ammonium of sulfuric acid, can be natural or synthetic. 
  It is sometimes used to purify drinking water.    It is known that pure aluminum and ammonium sulfate is dangerous by ingestion and inhalation. 
 Chronic ingestion can affect the brain and bones.  
  In large doses it is suspected that it promotes the onset of Alzheimer's disease, or Parkinson's disease. 
 It can also cause kidney toxicity. 
 A Side effect of Aluminium is that it inhibits the uptake of B-vitamins.
title: Aluminium ammonium sulfate

info:
Prepared from natural salt.  It is obtained by electrolysis of sodium chloride. 
 Strong alkali used as acidity regulator. Also used to enhance the industrial peeling of fruits, also to blacken olives and in the preparation of caramel. 
 It is found in many products, including bakery goods, cocoa products, coffee creamer, black olives. Acceptable daily intake is not determined. 
  In low doses it is safe and harmless. But in high doses can cause irritation of the digestive tract. 
 It is a harmful heavy metal by bioaccumulation and in a very low dose.
title: Sodium hydroxide

info:
Prepared from the natural salt potassium chloride. Potassium hydroxide is produced by electrolysis of potassium chloride. 
 Strong alkali used as acidity regulator. 
 Also used to enhance the industrial peeling of fruits and to blacken olives. 
 Found in Products like Bakery goods, cocoa products, black olives and the colour annatto (E160b) Acceptable daily intake is not determined.  
 Sodium does not exist as a pure body in nature, but it is very abundant in the form of compounds, for example, in table salt, essentially composed of sodium chloride.  
  In low doses it is safe and harmless. But in high doses can cause irritation of the digestive tract.
title: Potassium hydroxide

info:
Calcium hydroxide is a synthetic substance, obtained by mixing quick lime (calcium oxide, E529) with water. Prepared from the natural salt calcium oxide.  
  In the laboratory, this can be achieved by mixing an aqueous solution of calcium chloride (E509) with sodium hydroxide (E524). 
 Strong alkali used as acidity regulator, for example in wine. A solution of calcium hydroxide can be used to preserve eggs.   
 This additive is used for food, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, cement and other construction materials.   
   In low doses it is safe and harmless. 
 But in high doses can cause irritation of the digestive tract.
title: Calcium Hydroxide

info:
Prepared from the ammonia and water. Ammonium hydroxide is a solution formed from ammonia, a gas with an extremely irritating odor. 
 The industrial production is mainly by direct synthesis from dihydrogen and nitrous. 
  This additive is discouraged, as there may be risks of skin reactions, digestive disorders, ulcers and blood disorders. 
 The results suggest that exposure to ammonia may promote gastric cancer induced by other substances.  
 This additive is used for food, pharmaceutical, cosmetic and other products.
title: Ammonium hydroxide

info:
Prepared from natural minerals. Strong alkali used as acidity regulator. Magnesium hydroxide, exists in natural mineral form, but most of its industrial use would result from synthetic production, especially due to seawater. 
 This additive is used for food, pharmaceutical, cosmetic and other products.    In low doses, no side effects have been found. However, in large doses it can cause irritation of the digestive tract or laxative effect. 
  Keep in mind that it can disturb the absorption of folic acid (vitamin B9) and iron.
title: Magnesium hydroxide

info:
Prepared from chalk and used as an acidity regulator. Calcium oxide is obtained by calcination of calcium carbonate (E170).  
 Lime is a potentially dangerous product, used mainly in industry and agriculture. 
 It is also used in the preparation of intestines for sausages (as cover, not filling). Found in cocoa products, bakery products, intestines.
 Hydrophilic, it is used to dry and destroy organic matter rich in water. When mixing large amounts of quicklime and water, the heat released is such that the water can boil.   
  In low doses, no side effects have been found.
title: Calcium oxide

info:
Calcium Oxide is obtained by calcination of Magnesium Carbonate (E504).    Magnesium oxide exists in a natural mineral form, but it is also synthesized. 
  Found in Cocoa products and bakery products. Acceptable daily intake is not determined. 
 Magnesium acts as a laxative in high concentrations.  Magnesium acts as a laxative in high concentration. 
 Magnesium oxide is part of pharmaceuticals and is used as an antacid to treat heartburn, as a fast laxative in high concentration.    In low doses, no side effects have been found.
title: Magnesium oxide

info:
Sodium ferrocyanide is a synthetic product. It is manufactured industrially from hydrogen cyanide, iron chloride and calcium hydroxide. 
 It is interesting to note that the ferrocyanide salts become unstable and toxic in acid solutions. 
  As a food additive, there are no known side effects in doses below the daily intake. 
 Use is very limited, partly due to the strong yellow colour.
title: Sodium ferrocyanide

info:
Potassium ferrocyanide is a synthetic product. It is manufactured industrially from hydrogen cyanide, ferrous chloride and calcium hydroxide and potassium carbonate 
 Used as anti-caking agent and to remove copper from red wine. Copper is used as a fungicide on grapes. 
   It is interesting to note that the ferrocyanide salts become unstable and toxic in acid solutions.  
  As a food additive, there are no known side effects in doses below the daily intake.
title: Potassium ferrocyanide

info:
Potassium ferrocyanide is a synthetic product. It is manufactured industrially from hydrogen cyanide, ferrous chloride (E526), calcium hydroxide and calcium carbonate  
   It is interesting to note that the ferrocyanide salts become unstable and toxic in acid solutions. 
   As a food additive, there are no known side effects in doses below the daily intake.
title: Ferrous hexacyanomanganate

info:
Calcium ferrocyanide is a synthetic product. It is manufactured industrially from hydrogen cyanide, ferrous chloride (E526), calcium hydroxide and calcium carbonate.  
  It is interesting to note that the ferrocyanide salts become unstable and toxic in acid solutions.  
  As a food additive, there are no known side effects in doses below the daily intake.

info:
Sodium salt of thiosulfuric acid, synthetic. On an industrial scale, it is produced mainly from liquid waste from the production of sodium sulphide or from the production of sulfur dyes.  
  The toxicology of sodium thiosulfate has not been fully investigated. The pure compound can be reported for low toxicity. 
   Sodium thiosulfate is broken down in contact with acids and heat, with the emission of sulfur dioxide among others. It is better to avoid cooking with this additive.
title: Sodium thiosulfate

info:
Synthetic additive, is obtained from phosphoric acid derivative.  
  Pure phosphoric acid is a corrosive substance, harmful by ingestion and by contact or even by inhalation. 
   It is an additive that exists in many foods, it is important to take into account its high consumption.
title: Dicalcium diphosphate

info:
Synthetically produced from aluminium, phosphoric acid and sodium hydroxide. 
 .Aluminum and sodium salt of phosphoric acid, made of aluminum or aluminum oxide, phosphoric acid and sodium carbonate or hydroxide. 
  It is divided into 2 classes: Sodium and Aluminum Acid Phosphate (E541i) and Basic Sodium and Aluminum Phosphate (E541ii). 
   It is considered toxic additive since there are risks of accumulation of aluminum in certain tissues, several studies report neurotoxic effects, possible contribution with Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. 
 In cases of large doses there are risks such as toxins in the kidneys and heart.
title: Sodium aluminium phosphates

info:
Produced from animal bones. It consists of tricalcium phosphate, derived from steam under pressure or calcination of bone or ground bone of pigs. 
  Phosphates can be converted into polyphosphates, causing digestive disorders, blocking many enzymes.  
  It is considered that evidence was detected that bovine spongiform encephalopathy (the condition called "mad cow") could be caused by adding this additive in cattle feed.
title: Bone phosphate

title: Calcium sodium polyphosphate

info:
Produced by heating calcium phosphate. Used as emulsifier and stabiliser. It is obtained from derivative of Phosphoric Acid (E338).  
  In large doses can cause hyperactivity and digestive problems.  
  It is generally used to increase the mass of foods such as meats and sausages sold by weight.
title: Calcium Polyphosphates

info:
Inorganic salt of polyphosphoric acid and ammonia. Ammonium polyphosphate can be prepared by reacting concentrated phosphoric acid with ammonia.  
  Ammonium polyphosphate would also be used as chemical fertilizer and flame retardant in paints (pigments, binders and biocides) and in the manufacture / processing of pulp and paper. 
 It is also used as a nutrient for yeasts and increases the binding properties of water.
title: Ammonium Polyphosphates

info:
Phosphates are the natural salts of phosphoric acid (E338). Diphosphates consist of two molecules of condensed phosphates formed by phosphate heating. 
  Attention with this additive can cause loss of bone calcium. 
 In children it can cause hyperactivity and other behavioral disorders. Some studies say that it can promote the activity of known carcinogens.
title: Magnesium pyrophosphate

info:
Sodium silicate is formed naturally by the reaction of silica (or silicon dioxide, E551) with sodium carbonate (E500) in the molten state. It is a strong base that forms very alkaline, corrosive solutions for the skin and mucous membranes. 
  It is divided into 2 classes: Sodium Silicate and Sodium Metasilicate. 
 It is used in some pharmaceutical products, cosmetics, soaps and detergents. 
 The detergents that contain this product are powerful irritants for the skin, the eyes and the respiratory tract.
title: Sodium silicates

info:
Silicon dioxide is a combination of oxygen and synthetic silicon, but it also exists in abundance in nature. Silicon dioxide and silicates exist naturally in plant foods, particularly cereals. 
 It is used in various types of products: pharmaceuticals, perfumes, cosmetics and food manufacturing.    Silicon dioxide is generally considered harmless as an additive. However, silicon dioxide is one of the additives that today can be marketed in the form of nanoparticles. Food nanotechnology poses serious health problems in the medium and long term, and is not sufficiently regulated by law. 
 Since they can have (due to their very small size) very different toxicokinetic properties.
title: Silicon dioxide

info:
Calcium silicates exist in their natural state (limestone), but are produced by synthesis from the reaction of lime (E529) and silica (E551) in varying proportions. 
  It is authorized as an additive for the treatment of chewing gum by recovery, but it is also an additive support used especially in the manufacture of emulsifiers and dyes, in potassium chloride preparations for the purpose of salt replacement products.  
 It is also used for pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, various industrial uses.
title: Calcium silicate

info:
Produced from magnesium sulphate and sodium silicate or directly from minerals such as talcum, sepiolite and steatite. 
 Magnesium silicate is a natural crystalline mineral. 
 Commercially, it is an amorphous synthetic compound in the form of a powder formed by the reaction of a precipitate of water-soluble sodium silicate and a water-soluble magnesium salt such as magnesium chloride, nitrate or sulfate.   
 It is divided into 3 classes: Magnesium Silicate and Magnesium Talc. 
 They are considered harmful by inhalation.

info:
Sodium aluminosilicate is an acid salt that contains sodium, aluminum, silicon and oxygen. This includes synthetic amorphous sodium aluminosilicate, some natural minerals and synthetic zeolites. Synthetic amorphous sodium aluminosilicate is widely used as a food additive (E554).  
  It is potentially toxic and neurotoxic because of aluminum. Some reports link it to Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's.  
  Some sources report a harmful potential for bones and kidneys, the fetus and reproduction.   
  Apart from being used as a food additive, it is also used for pharmaceutical products.
title: Sodium aluminosilicate

info:
Aluminum potassium silicate is a potassium salt of silicic aluminum. 
 Muscovite and phlogopite are the two main commercial micas. Micas are usually found in ordinary rocks. With quartz and feldspar, it is one of the components of granite. It would be synthesized from calcined kaolinite. 
 It is potentially toxic and neurotoxic because of aluminum. Some reports link it to Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's. It is also harmful to the bones and kidneys and the fetus. 
 Apart from being used as a food additive, it is also used for pharmaceutical products.
title: Potassium aluminium silicate

info:
Calcium silicoaluminate is the calcium and aluminum salt of silicic acid, it exists naturally as a mineral species of the group of silicates (anortite), present especially in metamorphic and magmatic rocks. It can be produced industrially from calcium hydroxide and kaolinite, a mineral species composed of hydrated aluminum silicate.  
 It is potentially toxic and neurotoxic because of aluminum. 
 Some reports link it to Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's. It is also harmful to the bones and kidneys and the fetus.
title: Aluminium Calcium Silicate

info:
The zinc salt of silicic acid exists in its natural state in mineral form (Willemite). It is produced from silicon oxide (quartz) and zinc oxide.  
  Its function is to help prevent food particles from sticking. 
  It is also used in cosmetics (deodorants).  
  No side effects have been found.
title: Zinc silicate

info:
Bentonite is an absorbent hydrated aluminum silicate, mainly made of montmorillonite and clay, which makes it a water retainer.  
 The deposits of bentonite are of volcanic and hydrothermal origin. The main raw materials used in the industrial production of bentonite are bentonite ore, sulfuric acid and calcium oxide. 
 Also used as clarifying agent in fruit juice preparations. Found in fruit juices, aromas. Main use, however, is in cosmetics.  
   No side effects have been found.  
   It is used in the manufacture of lubricating greases, flavorings and as a wine clarifier. It is also used in animal feed to eliminate toxins. A natural type of clay from volcanic origin. Used as anti-caking agent and emulsifier.
title: Bentonite

info:
It comes from deposits derived from the local alteration of granitic rocks (feldspar). They are white clays composed mainly of aluminum silicates.  
  In food, this additive is often used in bakeries and pastry shops. But it is also used for beauty treatments such as exfoliating and bleaching the skin.  
   No side effects have been found. But there are reports that say it is better to avoid it because of the aluminum (E173) it contains.
title: Aluminium silicate

info:
Potassium salt of silicic acid, produced by supercooled fusion of potassium carbonate (E501) and pure silica sand (E551).  
  Not much is known about the toxicity of this additive, as it is not fully studied.  
  Besides using it in food, it is also used for cosmetics, anticorrosion, detergent manufacturing, glass, ceramics, welding rods, adhesives, cements, paints and others.

Fatty acids originally exist in animal and plant cells. Soy, corn, rapeseed and cotton are often used as raw materials and are usually transgenic. The use of animal fats (porcine and / or bovine) can not be excluded.  
  In large doses can cause serious adverse effects such as breast cancer, hypercholesterolemia, atherosclerosis, Diabetes (insulin resistance), cardiovascular risks, liver dysfunction. It is advisable to avoid it.
title: Fatty acids

info:
Ammonium salt of stearic acid. Used as anti-caking and anti-foaming agent in sugar production. 
 Found in Sugar, but mainly used in cosmetics. 
 Acceptable daily intake is not determined. 
 Although stearic acid and stearates are commercially obtained from plant sources, the use of animal fat (including pork and beef) can not be excluded. Only the producer can provide information on the origin. 
 Few information. It is considered harmless, unless the powder is inhaled.
title: Ammonium stearate

info:
Magnesium stearate is a salt synthesized from stearic acid, a saturated fatty acid of animal or vegetable origin  and a bond with magnesium. 
 It also contains magnesium palmitate.     Cottonseed oil and palm oil are the crude vegetable fats most commonly reported in the manufacture of magnesium stearate. 
 The use of animal, porcine and / or bovine fats, however, are not excluded. Only the producer can provide this information. 
  It is considered harmless, unless the powder is inhaled.
title: Magnesium stearate

info:
Aluminum stearate is a salt synthesized from stearic acid (E570), a saturated fatty acid of animal or vegetable origin and a bond with aluminum.  
  At recommended doses, no side effects have been found. 
 But in large doses can lead to toxicity in the kidneys and accumulation of aluminum particles in the body. 
 In some reports it is believed that it can become neurotoxic. It is recommended to avoid it.
title: Aluminium stearate

 It is widely used in the cleaning of glass bottles before filling the drink or food. It is also used in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. 
 No side effects have been found.

info:
Natural amino acid (building block of protein).  
 Glutamic acid is a non-essential amino acid and the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system in mammals, and has an important role in learning and memory. 
 It is naturally present in many animal and vegetable proteins such as cheeses, tomatoes and algae. 
 Commercially prepared from molasses by bacterial fermentation. 
 In low doses it is potentially excitotoxic and neurotoxic since it is able to destroy neurons in the brain very quickly. 
 In large doses can cause allergic reactions and asthma attacks.

info:
Guanylic acid is a natural acid, which is part of RNA, one of the genetic carrier molecules in the cell.  
 Commercially, guanilic acid can be isolated from RNA by the enzymatic degradation that is generally obtained from yeasts or sardines, but it can also be biosynthesized directly from microorganisms or enzymes. 
 Mainly without known risk. But it is also better to avoid it since the commercial production of guanilic acid can be transgenic.  
  It is also advisable to avoid it: asthmatics, babies and small children, pregnant or lactating women.  
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells. 
 As guanylates are metabolised to purines, they should be avoided by people suffering from gout. 
 However, the concentrations used are generally so low that no effects are to be expected. Guanlyic acid and guanylates are generally produced from yeasts, but partly also from fish.
title: Guanylic acid

info:
Sodium salt of guanylic acid , a natural acid, which is part of RNA, one of the genetic carrier molecules in the cell. It is thus part of all cells in all living organisms. 
 Commercially prepared from yeast extract or sardines. A flavour enhancer having specific umami taste but strongly enhance many other flavours, thereby reducing the amounts of salt needed in a product. 
 Acceptable daily intake is not determined. Guanylates may not be used in products intended for children under 12 weeks. Asthmatic people should avoid guanylic acid and guanylates. 
 As guanylates are metabolised to purines, they should be avoided by people suffering from gout. However, the concentrations used are generally so low that no effects are to be expected. 
 Guanlyic acid and guanylates are generally produced from yeasts, but partly also from fish.

But it is also better to avoid it since the commercial production of guanilic acid can be transgenic.

info:
Inosinic acid is a commercially obtained nucleotide of Torula yeast. 
  Inosinic acid occurs naturally in muscle tissue. It also occurs during the decomposition of meat. 
  Commercially, it is prepared from meat, fish or by potentially transgenic bacterial fermentation. 
 In small doses, no secondary effect was found. In large doses can cause: hyperactivity, irritation of mucous membranes, insomnia, allergies and is recommended to avoid in patients who have kidney diseases.   
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells.
title: Inosinic acid

info:
The inosinates are the salts of inosinic acid, which chemically bind the latter with sodium. 
 Inosinic acid is a commercially obtained nucleotide of Torula yeast.  
  Inosinic acid occurs naturally in muscle tissue. It also occurs during the decomposition of meat. 
 Commercially, it is prepared from meat, fish or by potentially transgenic bacterial fermentation. 
 In small doses, no secondary effect was found. In large doses can cause: hyperactivity, irritation of mucous membranes, insomnia, allergies and is recommended to avoid in patients who have kidney diseases. 
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells.
title: Disodium 5’-inosinate

info:

 Inosinic acid is a commercially obtained nucleotide of Torula yeast.  
  Inosinic acid occurs naturally in muscle tissue. It also occurs during the decomposition of meat.

 In small doses, no secondary effect was found. In large doses can cause: hyperactivity, irritation of mucous membranes, insomnia, allergies and is recommended to avoid in patients who have kidney diseases. 
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells.
title: Potassium 5’-inosinate

info:
The inosinates are the salts of inosinic acid, which chemically bind the latter with potassium. 
 Inosinic acid is a commercially obtained nucleotide of Torula yeast.  
  Inosinic acid occurs naturally in muscle tissue. It also occurs during the decomposition of meat. 
 Commercially, it is prepared from meat, fish or by potentially transgenic bacterial fermentation. 
 In small doses, no secondary effect was found. In large doses can cause: hyperactivity, irritation of mucous membranes, insomnia, allergies and is recommended to avoid in patients who have kidney diseases. 
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells.
title: Calcium inosinate

info:
Ribonucleotides are a mixture of guanylates and inosinates.  
Guanylates and inosinates are the salts of guanylic and inosinic acid. These natural acids can be produced using transgenic technologies. It is difficult to determine case by case and to what extent. 
 The additives manufactured in closed systems with the help of transgenic microorganisms are not labeled as such, since it is considered that the additive has been purified and no longer contains microorganisms. In the case that the microorganisms in question have received nutrients (substrate) from transgenic plants, the additive is not identified as such. 
 Not recommended in children and pregnant women. Our organism once metabolized transforms it into uric acid, which is deposited in the tissues and can cause gout (pain in the joints). In large doses can cause hyperactivity, asthma, skin reactions, insomnia, allergy and irritation of the mucous membranes. 
 It is a commercially obtained nucleotide of Torula yeast cells.
title: Calcium 5’-ribonucleotides

info:
Ribonucleotides are a mixture of guanylates and inosinates. 
 Guanylates and inosinates are guanylic salts and inosinic acid. These natural acids can be produced using transgenic technologies. 
 In small doses, no secondary effect was found. In large doses can cause: hyperactivity, irritation of mucous membranes, insomnia, allergies and is recommended to avoid in patients who have kidney diseases. 
 The nucleotides are commercially obtained from Torula yeast cells.
title: Sodium ribonucleotides

info:
Natural maltol is found in the bark of young larches, pine needles, chicory and wood tars.    Maltol is produced by synthesis for use in perfumery and aromatic foods. 
 In low doses no side effects have been found. But in large doses can cause benign abdominal pain. There are reports where there is a carcinogenic risk.
title: Maltol

info:
The ethyl maltol is derived from ethylenically Maltol (E636), being 6 times sweeter than maltol itself.    Natural maltol is found in the bark of young larches, pine needles, chicory and wood tars.    Maltol is produced by synthesis for use in perfumery and aromatic foods. 
   In low doses no side effects have been found. 
 But in large doses can cause benign abdominal pain. 
 There are reports where there is a carcinogenic risk.
title: Ethyl Maltol

info:
Sodium aspartate is the sodium salt of aspartic acid, one of the 20 amino acids that make up proteins. It plays a role in the functions of the nervous system (neurotransmitter?) And the production and release of hormones Aspartic acid can be found naturally in certain vegetables, dried fruits, meats, sugar cane / sugar beets. 
 It is also supplied in the form of dietary supplements, to be consumed in a controlled manner. 
 Very little is known about this additive. Benign gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, have been reported. 
 Due to the lack of long-term studies, L-aspartate salts should be avoided in children, pregnant women and lactating women.
title: Sodium L-aspartate

info:
Non-essential amino acid produced by muscle cells. Among other things, it is useful for the nervous system, immunity, energy and sugar metabolism. 
 It is found mainly in meats and fish. To date, no side effects are known. 
 This additive is also used in pharmaceutical and cosmetic products.
title: Alanine

info:
Glycine is a non-essential amino acid found in many proteins and is abundant in gelatin (E428), sugar cane, peanuts, almonds, meat and fish. In particular, it plays a neurotransmitter role in the central nervous system. 
 Discovered in 1820 by boiling gelatin and sulfuric acid (E513), the commercial production is synthetic and diversified. 
 To date, no side effects are known.
title: Glycine and its sodium salt

info:
Leucine is an essential amino acid with a sweet taste found in wheat germs, potatoes, fish / tuna, meat and peanuts. 
 The control of blood glucose is one of its many functions. It can be manufactured in various ways, including by isolation of gluten, casein or keratin (animal proteins), by hydrolysis of proteins (edestine, hemoglobin, zein) by bromination followed by amination of isocaproic acid from hydantoin. 
 In low doses, no side effects have been found, but in large doses it can cause stomach upset, prevent the absorption of other amino acids and cause an increase in ammonia levels in the blood, which can be toxic to the liver and kidneys.
title: Leucine

info:
Lysine is an essential amino acid. Commercial lysine is usually made by microbiological fermentation. 
 There is also a synthetic process that combines chemical and microbiological techniques of caprolactam and L-ACL-hydrolase. No secondary effect was found. 
 Since the chemical is an amino acid bound to hydrochloric acid, it is not toxic a priori. 
 It is used in some pharmaceutical and cosmetic products.
title: Lysin hydrochloride

info:
Acetates are the salts of acetic acid E260, which are chemically bound to the latter with potassium, sodium, calcium, ammonia or zinc to form acetates. 
  Zinc acetate is generally reported without known danger, in the dosage of food. Some authors recommend caution.   
 It is used in chewing gum to freshen breath and fight bacterial plaque. It is also used as a dietary supplement, in cold packs and in the treatment of acne.
title: Zinc acetate
