info:
It is obtained by hydrolysis and polycondensation of dichlorodimethylsilane and chlorotrimethylsilane. (It is used especially in breast implants). 
  It is divided into 2 classes: Polydimethylsiloxane and Polymethylphenylsiloxane. 
 It is also used in treatment for hair and in pharmaceutic products.    
 In low doses no side effects have been found. But in large doses can cause kidney problems, liver and nervous system. 
 There are reports where there is a carcinogenic risk.
title: Dimethyl-polysiloxane

info:
It is obtained by hydrolysis and polycondensation of dichlorodimethylsilane and chlorotrimethylsilane. (It is used especially in breast implants).  
  It is also used in treatment for hair and in pharmaceutical products.
  In low doses no side effects have been found. 
 But in large doses can cause kidney problems, liver and nervous system. 
 There are reports where there is a carcinogenic risk.
title: Polydimethylsiloxane

info:
It is obtained by hydrolysis and polycondensation of dichlorodimethylsilane and chlorotrimethylsilane.  (It is used especially in breast implants).  
 It is also used in hair treatment and pharmaceutical products.  
 In low doses no side effects have been found. 
 But in large doses can cause kidney problems, liver and nervous system. 
 There are reports where there is a carcinogenic risk.
title: Methylphenylpolysiloxane

info:
Natural polymer produced by bees.  Beeswax is the particular wax secreted by honey bees, which they use to build honeycombs. 
 Beeswax can initially contain impurities because it has a strong affinity for industrial pollutants and pesticides.     
 It is divided into 2 classes: White Beeswax and Yellow Beeswax. 
 In low doses, no side effects have been found.  
 But it must be said that in some cases this substance is not reabsorbed by the body, difficult to digest. 
 And also the allergy is sometimes reported at the level of cosmetics with this substance. 
 Acceptable daily intake is not determined.
title: Beeswax

info:
Natural polymer produced from the Mexican trees Euphorbia antisyphilitica , E. cerifera and Pedilanthus pavonis . 
   The wax is extracted by treatment with sulfuric acid and, naturally, contains almost 50% of hydrocarbons. 
  Used as a coating and used in chewing gum. Also found in confectionary. 
  No side effects were found.
title: Candelilla wax

info:
Carnauba wax comes from the leaves of a palm tree located partially in northeastern Brazil, Copernicia prunifera.  
 This wax is obtained by threshing the leaves, followed by refining and sometimes fading. 
  In low doses, no side effects have been found. But it must be said that in some cases it can cause small allergic reactions. 
 Used as a coating and in chewing gum products. Also found in confectionary, coffee and bakery products. 
 Carnauba wax is also widely used in cosmetics and can cause eczema.
title: Carnauba wax

info:
The Shellac is a lacquer that results from the secretion of an Asian cochineal, Kerria lacca. 
 The resin obtained is yellow / red amber, generally supplied in the form of flakes that dissolve in 95 ° alcohol. 
 The mixture obtained can be used in the manufacture of cabinets or in the manufacture of violins for varnishing wood.  
 Other applications are the food industry, pharmaceutical products, the manufacture of adhesives or inks. 
  It is divided into 2 classes: White Lacquer Gum and Orange Lacquer Gum.     
 No side effects have been found. But sometimes they are suspected to be allergenic. 
 It has an allergenic potential by contact, with proven cases of allergic reactions when used as a cosmetic ingredient.
title: Shellac

info:
The paraffins are now obtained in oil refineries. They do not stick. They are not a binder, unlike beeswax (E901) and some vegetable waxes.    
 Microcrystalline wax is produced from waste when motor oils are conditioned. White, odorless wax is used as an ointment base or as a preservative for metal objects. 
 No side effects have been found in low doses. But in some cases there may be some difficulty in the absorption of many nutrients, minerals and vitamins. 
 Beware of pregnant women, it is better to avoid it. 
 It is known that the additive contains traces of at least one polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH), benzo (a) pyrene, which is very toxic.
title: Paraffins

info:
A mineral oil is a mixture derived from the distillation of certain fossil fuels. It is obtained by distillation of coal, oil or certain oil shales and serves mainly as a lubricant for mechanical parts of machines and engines. 
 Outside the U.E., it is sometimes used in the food industry, especially in confectionery. According to the US FDA UU (2015), the mineral oil that is eaten in or near meals interferes with the absorption of provitamin A and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D and K, and consequently with the use of calcium and phosphorus. 
 The mineral oils of aromatic hydrocarbons can be mutagenic and carcinogenic. 
 Daily intake: Up to 20 mg / kg of body weight.
title: Mineral oil

info:
Synthetic mixture of hydrocarbons used as coating, lubricant, solvent, Anti-foaming agent and in chewing gum. 
 Vaseline, as paraffin, an oil distillate. Its composition depends on the source of the oil and the refining process. The highly refined categories are used in pharmacy and cosmetics. 
 The less refined categories are used industrially and may contain impurities such as polycyclic aromatic carcinogens. A laxative effect is possible. 
 It can irritate or interfere with digestion, inhibit the absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. It can be dangerous in high doses. A contact allergy (dermatitis) is possible.
title: Petroleum jelly

info:
The paraffins are now obtained in oil refineries. They do not stick. 
 They are not a binder, unlike beeswax (E901) and some vegetable waxes.  Microcrystalline wax is produced from waste when motor oils are conditioned. 
 White, odorless wax is used as an ointment base or as a preservative for metal objects. 
  No side effects have been found in low doses. But in some cases there may be some difficulty in the absorption of many nutrients, minerals and vitamins. 
 Beware of pregnant women, it is better to avoid it. 
 It is known that the additive contains traces of at least one polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH), benzo (a) pyrene, which is very toxic.
title: Petroleum wax

 The mineral oils of aromatic hydrocarbons can be mutagenic and carcinogenic.  
 Daily intake: Up to 20 mg / kg of body weight.
title: Mineral oil, high viscosity

info:
A mineral oil is a mixture derived from the distillation of certain fossil fuels. 
 It is obtained by distillation of coal, oil or certain oil shales and serves mainly as a lubricant for mechanical parts of machines and engines. Outside the U.E., it is sometimes used in the food industry, especially in confectionery. 
 The mineral oils of aromatic hydrocarbons can be mutagenic and carcinogenic.  
 Daily intake: Up to 20 mg / kg of body weight.
title: Mineral oil, medium and low viscosity

info:
A mineral oil is a mixture derived from the distillation of certain fossil fuels. 
 It is obtained by distillation of coal, oil or certain oil shales and serves mainly as a lubricant for mechanical parts of machines and engines. 
 The mineral oils of aromatic hydrocarbons can be mutagenic and carcinogenic.  Daily intake: Up to 20 mg / kg of body weight.
title: Mineral oil, medium and low viscosity, class II

info:
A mineral oil is a mixture derived from the distillation of certain fossil fuels. 
 It is obtained by distillation of coal, oil or certain oil shales and serves mainly as a lubricant for mechanical parts of machines and engines. 
 The mineral oils of aromatic hydrocarbons can be mutagenic and carcinogenic.
title: Mineral oil, medium and low viscosity, class III

info:
Benzoin resin is a reddish brown solid with a vanilla odor, it is a balsamic resin obtained from the bark of several Styrax tree species. 
 It is used in perfumes, certain types of incense and in medicine (see benzoin tincture). 
 Its main component is often benzoic acid. No secondary effect was found. 
 It is unlikely that the pure substance and / or its dye will cause irritation, allergy or contact dermatitis. 
 It additive is rarely used as a food additive. It is used in cosmetics, perfumery and pharmaceuticals.
title: Benzoin gum

info:
It is obtained from oil. It is a mixture of hydrocarbons synthesized from pure 1-Decene.    
 Polydecene is also found in motor oils for automobiles, cosmetics, shampoos, lipsticks and some pharmaceutical products, such as skin care creams and anti-odor bars. 
 This additive toxicity is high because in high doses can cause poor absorption of vitamins and minerals. 
 It can cause hemorrhages in pregnant women. 
 Recent WHO studies showed that traces of mineral oils were found in the liver and lymph.
title: hydrogenated polydecene

info:
Rice bran wax is a vegetable wax extracted from rice bran oil (Oryza sativa). 
 Its main components are aliphatic acids (wax acids) and esters. Rice bran oil is obtained by making white or polished rice (which is actually the endosperm of Oryza sativa L., grass seed). 
 A refined wax extracted from rice bran. The refining involves one or more chemical treatments and the consequent loss of nutritional intake. 
 The use of solvents during the production process also implies the presence of residual traces generally toxic. 
 Rice bran wax is found in a variety of uses such as paper coating, textiles, fruit and vegetable coatings, pharmaceuticals, chewing gum and cosmetics.
title: Rice bran wax

info:
The white of the whale is a white substance in the head of certain cetaceans, like the sperm whale. The corresponding organ is called the spermaceti organ. 
 It is extracted from the spermaceti oil by crystallization during a pressure treatment and an alkaline chemical solution. 
 Due to its properties, the target of the whale was very sought after for the realization of candles, soaps, cosmetics, lubricants or similar pharmaceutical excipients.
title: Spermaceti wax

info:
A naturally occuring sulphur containing amino acid, derived from cystine, that the body needs to produce Glutathione, one of the body's major antioxidants. 
 Esters of a fatty acid and a long-chain alcohol. These oils have properties similar to those of triglycerides, but they are not digestible. 
 They are found in some fish like the orange clock. 
 Wax esters are also found in certain plants, especially in jojoba, and in some bacteria, such as certain Acinetobacter, in which they are used as energy reserves. 
  In compound form (E920 and E921) it is used in flour and bakery products (except wholemeal) where it is used as an improving agent and in chicken stock cubes where it is used as a flavour. 
 Currently no side effects have been found.
title: Wax esters

info:
The methyl esters of the fatty acids are organic aliphatic esters prepared essentially by reaction of a carboxylic acid (derived from natural fats and oils) and methanol. 
 They consist of fatty acids of animal or vegetable origin. 
 They are used indirectly in a wide range of foods, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and industrial applications, especially as diesel biofuels or biodiesel. 
 No one has been able to participate at this time. It can be derived from vegetable oils such as rapeseed and, therefore, a transgenic biotechnology.
title: Methyl esters of fatty acids

info:
Esters of montanic acid (a saturated fatty acid) are derived from a chemical preparation of mountain wax, extracted by a solvent, found in lignite (brown coal). 
 The esterification is carried out using ethylene glycol, 1,3-butanediol or triols. In 2013, given the limitations of toxicological data, the Scientific Committee of EFSA concluded that the additive could not be evaluated. 
 Some sources report it as acceptable or without known side effects. But there are some sources that report it as an additive to avoid, suspected of being allergic and carcinogenic.
title: Montan wax

info:
A yellow fat secreted by the sebaceous glands of the sheep and extracted from their wool. 
 Used as an emollient, cosmetic and pharmaceutical auxiliary. 
 This complex mixture of esters of alcohols and fatty acids is chemically classified as wax and naturally serves as a waterproofing agent for wool animals. 
 It is used as a glaze in some traditional sweets, and to give a bright coating to candies and chewing gum. It is also used to produce vitamin D3, natural cosmetics, balms, moisturizing ointments, emollient products, lipsticks, cocoa, lip repair and extra moisturizing creams. 
  Its toxicity is very low, although in some cases it can cause allergic reactions of small intensity. 
 There is little information about its use in food.
title: Lanolin

info:
Synthetic product of petrochemical origin. Polyethylene is a milky, firm and flexible translucent plastic prepared by the polymerization of liquid ethylene. 
 Wash hands thoroughly after peeling the fruit treated with this additive. Poor absorption of vitamins and minerals. 
 It can cause bleeding in pregnant women if large amounts are consumed. In 1991, studies by FAO and WHO showed that there were traces of mineral oils in the liver and lymph, and in 1995 this same Committee showed that certain lesions could be observed in rats as well as in humans due to residues of said oils The pure substance (powder form) shows some signs of carcinogenic activity in laboratory animals, but it is not classified as carcinogenic in humans.
title: Oxidized polyethylene wax

info:
Rosin is the solid residue obtained after the distillation of turpentine, oleoresin, a substance extracted from coniferous trees and, in particular, pine (genus Pinus). 
 It is also used to give Citrus flavour. 
 Colophony is an irritant and allergen for the skin (dermatitis) and respiratory tract (asthma), in pure form or by its degradation products, without the mechanisms of action are still well known. 
 Pure rosin is dangerous by ingestion, it can be toxic to the lungs and skin.     
 The ester of rosin is used in the manufacture of beverages and chewing gum, in the coatings industry (manufacture of lacquers, paints, varnishes), pharmaceuticals (see rosin) and cosmetics.
title: Pentaerithrytol esters of colophane

info:
Calcium salt of iodine acid, prepared by passing chlorine in a solution of hot lime containing dissolved iodine. 
 Iodines are used particularly in medicine for iodine deficiency, the treatment of goiter and the protection of the thyroid in the radioactive perimeters. 
 Possible nausea at therapeutic doses. 
 To date, iodates are not listed as food additives (that is, with an 'E' code) for the European Union. 
 They are allowed in more specific food fields, such as mineral salts that are added to cereals and baby food.
title: Calcium iodate

info:
Iodine as a pure substance is a powerful oxidizing agent, mainly poisoned by the GI tract and direct toxicity against the cells of the retina. 
 May cause a fire in contact with flammable or even combustible materials. 
 Iodine is used especially in medicines for iodine deficiency and the treatment of thyroid hyperplasia and the protection of the thyroid in radioactive oceans. Possible nausea at therapeutic doses. 
 To date, iodine has not been included as a food additive of the European Union, but its use is permitted in more specific food areas, such as: mineral salts added to cereals and baby food.
title: Potassium iodate

info:
Nitric oxide can be manufactured industrially by passing air through an electric arc by oxidizing the ammonia to a platinum gauze. 
 Nitrogen dioxide is produced by oxidation of nitric acid. Nitrogen oxides are proven pollutants, harmful both to the environment and to health. 
 It has been reported that nitrogen dioxide as a pure substance, among other things, reacts with the blood and forms methemoglobin.
title: Oxides of nitrogen

info:
Nitrosyl chloride is a yellow gas that is most often found as a decomposition product of aqua regia, a mixture of hydrochloric acid and nitric acid. 
 It can be manufactured in various ways, including by the reaction of chlorine with sodium nitrate. 
 Very toxic gas in its pure state. Pure nitrosyl chloride is a highly toxic and corrosive gas. Inhalation causes severe irritation of the respiratory tract and damages the mucous membranes.
title: Nitrosyl chloride

info:
Cysteine is an amino acid found in a wide variety of foods, especially cereals. It participates in the synthesis of melanin, which is the natural pigment of the skin and hair.  
 It can be obtained, among other things, by dissolving with hydrochloric acid feathers, pig hair or even human hair. This last mode of production is prohibited today.
title: Cysteine

info:
Cysteine is an amino acid found in a wide variety of foods, especially cereals. It participates in the synthesis of melanin, which is the natural pigment of the skin and hair.  
  It can be obtained, among other things, by dissolving with hydrochloric acid feathers, pig hair or even human hair. This last mode of production is prohibited today. 
  It is a bread enhancer and stabilises the structure of leavened bread. 
 Acceptable daily intake is not determined.
title: Cystine (L-) and its hydrochlorides – sodium and potassium salts

info:
Potassium persulfate is a potassium salt of peroxydisulfuric acid. The latter is an oxo acid of sulfur, a strong oxidant that is used, among other things, in certain metal pickling. 
 Pure potassium persulfate is classified as harmful and dangerous. 
 If ingested it is irritating to the eyes, the skin and the respiratory tract, it is a sensitizer, its combustion can produce corrosive and toxic gases, while the waste can contaminate the environment.
title: Potassium persulfate

info:
Ammonium salt of peroxydisulfuric acid (or Marshall acid). 
 The latter is an oxo acid of sulfur (a compound containing sulfur, oxygen and hydrogen), it is in its pure state a strong oxidant that is used, among other things, in certain metal pickling. 
 Ammonium is naturally present in our body as a waste of metabolism, comes from the breakdown of proteins and is essentially produced by the intestine, kidneys and muscles (depleted by stress) to be eliminated by the liver. 
 It is a compound additive that is very harmful to humans. 
 Pure ammonium persulfate is a compound that is harmful by ingestion and is very destructive to mucous membranes, is not stable with water and is incompatible with organic matter.
title: Ammonium persulfate

info: improving agent
title: Potassium bromate

info:
Potassium salt of bromic acid, a synthetic compound that can be produced by passing bromine to a solution of potassium hydroxide.     
 A pure substance is recognized as toxic by ingestion, inhalation or contact. In particular, it is incompatible with organic matter. It is very dangerous for the human. 
 There are official reports that it can be carcinogenic to humans. It is not advisable to avoid this additive.  
 Potassium bromate is also a cosmetic component (used as neutralizers or oxidants in hair curling preparations) and is also used as an industrial cleanser.
title: Potassium bromate

info:
Calcium salt of bromic acid, a synthetic compound that can be produced by passing bromine to a solution of calcium hydroxide. 
  A pure substance is recognized as toxic by ingestion, inhalation or contact. In particular, it is incompatible with organic matter. It is very dangerous for the human. 
 There are official reports that it can be carcinogenic to humans. 
 Calcium bromate is also a cosmetic component (used as neutralizers or oxidants in hair curling preparations) and is also used as an industrial cleanser.
title: Calcium bromate

info:
Chlorine as a single substance is a gas with a stifling odor that is very unpleasant and extremely toxic. 
 In nature, chlorine is found only in combination with other elements, particularly sodium chloride (table salt), in this form it is necessary for many life forms.  
 Its use for the disinfection of drinking water or pools generates dangerous products for our health.  
  It is used as a flour treatment (bleaching) agent.  It is also used for pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, the production of antiseptics, dyes, insecticides, paints and others.
title: Chlorine

info:
Obtained from chlorine and sodium chlorite. 
 Chlorine dioxide is prepared synthetically, it is a reddish yellow gas. It is relatively stable in its gaseous and liquid state. In practice, it is never used in pure form. 
 It is known that the pure substance is very toxic by ingestion, inhalation and contact, is particularly incompatible with organic matter and forms hydrogen chloride with water. 
 It is used as a flour treatment (bleaching) agent.   It is also used for pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, the production of antiseptics, dyes, insecticides, paints and others.
title: Chlorine dioxide

info:
Obtained from carbonamide. The raw materials used or used in the production are sodium hydroxide, sulfuric acid (E513), hydrogen peroxide, urea (E927b), chlorine (E925), hydrazinium. 
 Sodium hypochlorite (bleach), sodium chlorate, chromic acid, nitrogen dioxide (E918) and biurea.  
 Chemically, pure azodicarbonamide is harmful and can act as a respiratory and cutaneous sensitizer, acute effects are a possibility of gastrointestinal disorders. 
  Azodicarbonamide is bound to urea, the main waste excreted in the urine.  
 It is used in flour with low gluten content to condition and strengthen the dough. And it is also used to whiten flour.
title: Azodicarbonamide

info:
Obtained from ammonia and carbon dioxide. Used as nutrient in fermented products. 
 . According to the JECFA informed by the WHO, the use at levels of up to 3% in chewing gum (only foods allowed to date, undated) is not a cause for concern. 
 It is known that the pure substance causes acute effects (ingestion) nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diuretic effect and sore throat. 
 Data among other mutagens, reprotoxic and tumorigenic reported by the American RTECS. 
 Some other users: pharmaceutical products, cosmetics, ruminants of reproduction (urea as a nutritional additive in the diet, some sectors of differentiated quality prohibit their use), teeth whitening (carbamide peroxide).
title: Urea (Carbamide)

info:
Obtained from benzoylchloride and sodium peroxide. 
  This product explodes in the dry state with shock, friction or high temperature. 
 It is known that the pure substance is very dangerous by ingestion (acute or chronic effects). It is also very reactive and oxidizing, it is an explosive when it is not diluted. 
 It is used for pharmaceutical products (including anti-acne with possible side effects), cosmetics as an active ingredient in teeth whitening systems, hair dyes and others
title: Benzoyl peroxide

info:
Acetone peroxide is a primary explosive discovered in 1895 by Richard Wolffenstein. 
 It is a family of unstable molecules that consist of cyclic organic peroxides. 
 More often it is in the form of a white crystalline powder. It has a characteristic pungent smell. 
 Pure acetone peroxide is a compound known to be very unstable and explosive. 
 It is made of hydrogen peroxide and acetone, two chemicals that are questionable or harmful by ingestion.
title: Acetone peroxide

info:
Calcium peroxide dissolves in acids to form hydrogen peroxide. 
 Bread enhancer and bleaching agent for flour but practically not used. 
 Pure calcium peroxide is a strong oxidizing agent with acute effects and is corrosive and very dangerous by ingestion, inhalation and contact. 
 The users of calcium peroxide are cosmetics, agriculture, aquaculture and soil restoration and others.
title: Calcium peroxide

info:
Natural inert gas and propellant. Found in Canned products. 
 Argon is a rare, colorless, tasteless and odorless gas that constitutes 0.9% of the air we breathe in the earth, it is used as a propellant (in aerosols) and gas for packaging.    Its non-reactive nature makes it compatible with food products. 
 Products without oxygen are protected against oxidation damage and are also protected against the invasion of bacteria and fungi. 
 Obtained commercially by distillation of liquid air. 
 No side effects were found.
title: Argon

info:
Natural inert gas and propellant.  Helium is a gas. 
 It is used as a propellant and as a stabilizer for packaged products. 
 Including products sensitive to air or oxygen, such as dairy products. 
 Like other noble gases, helium is extremely stable and does not easily form compounds with other elements.  
 Helium, which is neutral under standard conditions, is non-toxic, has no biological role and is found in minute quantities in human blood.  
 For large-scale use, helium is extracted by fractional distillation of natural gas, which can contain up to 7%.  
 No side effects have been found. In large quantities it causes the voice to become sharper for a few seconds.
title: Helium

info:
The dichlorodifluoromethane E940 is listed as gaz propellant. 
 It is used as an additive for food and cosmetics. 
 Dichlorodifluoromethane is also sold under the name Freon-12 or R12 according to the list of fluorinated and refrigerant gases, it is a chlorofluorocarbon dangerous to the ozone layer and is used as a propellant in aerosols until its manufacture was banned in 1995. 
 This is a greenhouse gas used as a propellant in aerosols. 
 According to the consulted sources, the additive E940 can be reported as toxic, it is not particularly good for human health but there are few risks in low doses, on the other hand, in large doses it can be carcinogenic.
title: Dichlorodifluormethane

info:
Natural inert gas and propellant. Nitrogen is a gas.  It is used as a propellant and as a stabilizer for packaged products. 
 It is also used as a freezing agent, especially in some kitchens they use it for desserts (such as to aerate some creams or mousses in order to give it more creaminess). 
 No side effects have been found.
title: Nitrogen

info:
Natural inert gas and propellant. Natural greenhouse gas, manufactured chemically from ammonium nitrate. 
 Also called nitrous oxide, it is classified as a pollutant by the Kyoto Protocol. 
 Sometimes it is reported to be toxic, but it is considered safe if it is used only as a propellant in the diet and not in high doses. 
 Its use is not recommended during the first trimester of pregnancy. 
 Nitrous oxide is also found in: pharmaceuticals (general anesthesia) and cosmetics (propellant).
title: Nitrous oxide

info:
Butane is obtained from petroleum fractions by pressure distillation of G.P.L (liquefied petroleum gases). 
 It is also a component of lit cigarettes. Butane is used or intended to be used to displace or suppress oxygen in the processing, storage or packaging of beverage products and other foods, with the exception of fresh meat. 
 It is a propeller in pastry pumps made of vegetable oil. No side effects known to date in the use of food. 
 There are carcinogenic effects in laboratory animals. In high doses, pure butane is potentially narcotic. Butane E 943a contains very small and harmful residual amounts: methane and butadiene (a known carcinogen).
title: Butane

info:
The hydrocarbon is found as a gas under normal conditions of temperature and pressure. 
 The main source of isobutane is the refining of crude oil by catalytic or reformed cracking and natural gas fields. 
 Very flammable It can ignite in the presence of static electricity. It is particularly a propeller in vegetable oil-based pastry pumps. 
 This gas is odorless and colorless and the odor is so strong that the cylinders are added later for greater safety in the event of a gas leak. 
 It is used as fuel, solvent, coolant and food additive. 
 It is used in aerosols such as oil sprays, butter, cream and other products.
title: Isobutane

info:
Gas derived from other petroleum products by thermochemical processes of gas or oil. 
 It is commonly used as a source of chemical energy by combustion in internal combustion engines, barbecues and boilers. 
 It is used as fuel, solvent, coolant and food additive. 
 It is used, among other things, for vegetable oils and aqueous emulsions to spray. 
 It is also used as a propellant in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, as well as fuel or fuel.
title: Propane

info:
Chloropentafluoroethane is a chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) used as a refrigerant. It is a transparent, colorless gas with an ethereal smell. 
 Vapors may cause dizziness or suffocation without warning. 
 Contact with this gas or liquefied gas can cause burns, serious injury and / or freezing.  
 It is prohibited by the Montreal Protocol because of its potential to destroy ozone. This prohibition does not affect industrial foods and certain medical applications.
title: Chloropentafluorethane

info:
Transparent, colorless gas with an ethereal (weak) odor. Octafluorocyclobutane vapors may cause dizziness or suffocation without warning. 
 Fire can produce irritating, corrosive and / or toxic gases. 
  In animals, the acute effects of this pure gas by inhalation are: possibility of cardiac arrhythmia, possibility of bronchoconstriction.
title: Octafluorcyclobutane

info:
Natural gas. Oxygen, commonly known as oxygen, is a transparent, colorless, odorless, tasteless and non-flammable gas. It is obtained by distillation of the air. 
 It is used in aerosols such as oil sprays, butter, cream and other products. It is also used for packaging. 
 
 Acceptable daily intake is not determined.
title: Oxygen

info:
Natural gas. Hydrogen, commonly known as hydrogen, is a colorless and odorless natural gas, very abundant, present in water and all organic components. 
 It is obtained by natural gas catalysis. It is the most abundant element in the universe. 
 It is used in aerosols such as oil sprays, butter, cream and other products. It is also used for packaging.
title: Hydrogen

info:
This additive is approximately 200 times sweeter than sugar, stable to heat. 
 As it has a bitter taste, it is usually combined with other sweeteners such as Aspartame and Sucralose. 

 According to a 2005 study tested in mice, it is interpreted that consumed in the long term could be carcinogenic (with higher incidence of cancer in males) and be linked to neurological problems, hyperglycemia and insulin secretion.
title: Acesulfame potassium

info:
Intense sweeteners, such as aspartame, acesulfame K and saccharin, provide virtually no calories and are mainly used in diet products.. Synthetic low calorie sweetener. 
 There are reports that show that there are more common side effects such as weight deregulation, the formation of different forms of cancer and the effect on the brain.
title: Aspartame

info:
It is obtained by a reaction of Cyclohexylamine with Sulfamic Acid or Sulfur Trioxide. 
 This additive is a synthetic low calorie sweetener. It is up to 40 times sweeter than ordinary sugar, but at the same time it is the artificial sweetener with less sweetness.  It is divided into 3 classes: Cyclamic Acid, Sodium Cyclamate and Calcium Cyclamate. 
 After several investigations, this additive is considered very toxic and could cause cancer if its consumption is not controlled. 
 It is advisable to avoid this additive.
title: Cyclamates

info:
Discovered in the 1960s, isomalt is made from sucrose and looks much like table sugar. It is white, crystalline and odourless. 
 Products made with isomalt have the same texture and appearance as those made with sugar. Because the same amount of isomalt is used in products as would be used if they were sweetened with sugar, isomalt containing products have the same appearance and texture as those made with sugar. 
 Found in boiled sweets, toffee, lollipops, fudge, wafers, cough drops, throat lozenges, and a wide variety of other products. 
 No side effects have been found. But in large doses can cause flatulations and diarrhea, like many other sugar alcohols.
title: Isomalt

info:
This artificial sweetening additive can be produced from toluene (methylbenzene), anthranilic acid (successive reaction with nitrous acid, sulfur dioxide, chlorine and ammonia). 
 Carcinogenic effects have been observed in guinea pigs. Subsequently, additional studies under the pressure of the food industry led to the elimination of this warning. 
 In low doses can present great risks of allergies. In large doses it causes bladder cancer in rats. 
 This product contains saccharin, which causes cancer in laboratory animals.
title: Saccharins

info:
Synthetic low calorie sweetener. It is up to 600 times sweeter than sugar. 
 In large doses causes the destruction of the immune system affecting mainly the liver and kidneys. 
 There are many studies that show that it can cause severe DNA damage.
title: Sucralose

info:
Synthetic low calorie sweetener. It is up to 2000 times sweeter than sugar. 
 No side effects have been found at the moment. But it is an additive that does not have much information about its toxicity in humans.
title: Alitame

info:
Sweetener 1600 to 3000 times sweeter than natural sugar. Thaumatin is a sugar protein, traditionally derived from the fruit of the African tropical plant \"katemfe\". 
 Its flavor is persistent, with a slight liqueur taste and its properties are used to modify flavors and not exclusively as a sweetener. 
 Thaumatin, consumed in high doses, seems to have mild laxative effects and cause mild abdominal pain, but the doses that should be ingested to know these drawbacks are extremely important.
title: Thaumatin

info:
Natural sweetener. It is derived from the licorice root. It has an aniseed and bittersweet flavor. 
 It is used as a substitute for sugar because it does not produce caries and is suitable for diabetics. 
 In high doses, glycyrrhizin may aggravate hypertension, water retention, hypokalemia (low potassium level) and other possible symptoms.
title: Glycyrrhizin

info:
Artificial  sweeter than sugar from grapefruit seed.  
 Synthetic sweetener and flavor enhancer. It is obtained by synthesis of a substance called 'neohesperidin' present in bitter oranges. 
 It is usually used together with other sweeteners. It is up to 1800 times sweeter than normal sugar. Its flavor is persistent, with a slight licorice taste and is used to mask bitter flavors. 
 NHDC is often presented as not dangerous. But in large doses it causes nausea and migraines.
title: Neohesperidine dihydrochalcone

info:
A natural sweetener extracted from the Stevia plant, 200 to 300 times sweeter than sucrose. 
 The additive is obtained from the leaves of Stevia rebaudiana Bertoni. 
 The leaves are extracted with hot water and the aqueous extract is passed through an adsorption resin to trap and concentrate the components of the steviol glycoside. 
 Some studies indicate that it could have long-term negative effects.
title: Steviol glycosides

info:
Synthetic low calorie sweetener and flavor enhancer. 
 It is obtained by chemical reaction of Aspartame with dimethylbutyl (dimethyl butyraldehyde), a compound that reduces the amount of phenylalanine and thus eliminates the obligation to include warnings about the risks of consumption of phenylalanine in the labeling of products. 
 It is up to 13,000 times sweeter than sugar. This additive is considered toxic and perhaps worse than aspartame, it is better to avoid it.
title: Neotame

info:
This additive is manufactured by the mixture of aspartame E951 and acesulfame E950. It is up to 350 times sweeter than sugar. 
 It is used in general in many products labeled as 'sugar free', '0% sugar', 'light', 'zero', 'zero' and 'low in calories'. 
 An additive to avoid is classified as a carcinogen by the association for therapeutic research against cancer.
title: Aspartame-acesulfame

info:
It is found naturally in dairy products, cocoa and some fruits, although it is usually obtained industrially derived from lactose, from which galactose is extracted in turn and reacted with enzymes of the fungus. 
 No side effects have been found. Do not abuse, in large doses can cause diarrhea, nausea or flatulence.
title: Tagatose

info:
The polyglycitol syrup belongs to hydrogenated starch hydrolyzate syrups consisting of maltitol (E965), sorbitol (E420) and higher molecular weight polyols. 
 No side effects have been found. Although disturbing results have been observed in rats, man would only be concerned about a possible laxative effect or gastric disorders.
title: Polyglycitol syrup

info:
Humectant, artificial sweetener base, bulking agent, base for essences. Starch decomposed with digestive enzymes. 
 Synthetic low calorie sweetener and support for additives. It is obtained from the sugars of malt. It is 25% less sweet than normal sugar. 
 It is marketed under the brands Amalty, Lesys, Maltisweet and SweetPearl. It is divided into two types of classes: Maltitol and Maltitol Syrup.
title: Maltitols

info:
Lactitol is a sugar alcohol (polyol) and is derived chemically from milk, specifically lactose, the sugar in milk. 
 Its sweetness is approximately 50% less sweet than natural sugar. 
 For the final product to be quite sweet, lactitol is often combined with the sweeteners aspartame (E 951) and acefulsame-K (E 950). 
 In small doses it can be laxative, cause diarrhea, flatulence and cramps. 
 In large doses can cause colic. It should be avoided in children under 3 years.
title: Lactitol

info:
A natural carbohydrate alcohol, present in many plants. 
 It is commercially produced from xylan, a polysaccharide fraction of wood pulp.
 A Low-calorie sweetener found in many bakery and confectionery products. 
 Acceptable Daily Intake is not defined. Xylitol is partly absorbed and metabolised as sugar by the body; the remaining fraction is fermented in the large intestine. During fermentation, gases are produced, which may cause bloating and flatulence. 
  Side effects normally occur after an intake of 25-30 grams in a single dose, which is far above the usage in normal foods. The term carbohydrate alcohol is a chemical definition; xylitol does not contain alcohol (ethanol).
title: Xylitol

info:
Present naturally in some fruits, vegetables and fermented foods, but the industrial production of erythritol is obtained by fermenting the flour (wheat and / or corn) and could be derived from GMOs. 
 Fermentation and due to the hydrolyzed enzyme and to an osmophilic yeast. The sweetening power of erythritol is 60 to 80% of the sugar. 
 No side effects have been found. In large doses it can have a laxative effect.
title: Erythritol

info:
Synthetic low calorie sweetener. It is obtained by combination of Aspartame and Vanillin. 
 Its flavor is up to 37,000 times sweeter than normal sugar. It is used to increase the flavor duration of chewing gum, to improve artificial substitutes with flavors of fruits, citrus and mint, and to reduce the high calorie content of some foods. 
 In large doses it can have a laxative effect and cause diarrhea.
title: Advantame

info:
It is obtained from a South American tree. It is often used in supplements and slimming pills to satisfy hunger. 
 Some reports say it is harmless while others consider it toxic to the blood and that it can cause intestinal inflammation.
title: Quillaia extracts
